content.description:
In a laboratory population of fruit flies, body color is determined by a single gene with a wild-type allele associated with black body color and a mutant allele associated with yellow body color. A group of researchers hypothesizes that the mutation in fruit flies that causes the yellow body is sex-linked. They also hypothesize that this mutation results in a change in the structure of the sex combs, bristle-like structures on the front legs of male flies that facilitate mating.

To determine the inheritance pattern of the mutant allele, researchers crossed yellow-bodied females with wild-type males. Flies from the <math alttext="F 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> generation were then crossed. content.question: Which of the following best supports the claim that the fitness of yellow-bodied flies is lower than the fitness of wild-type flies?

choices.label: Males with the yellow-body phenotype are selected by females for mating more often than are wild-type males.
Males with the yellow-body phenotype blend in with their environment and avoid detection by predators better than do wild-type males.
Males with the yellow-body phenotype reproduce less but produce a greater number of viable offspring than do wild-type flies.
Males with the yellow-body phenotype have weaker sex-comb bristles and decreased mating success compared with the bristles and mating success of wild-type males.

content.answer: Males with the yellow-body phenotype have weaker sex-comb bristles and decreased mating success compared with the bristles and mating success of wild-type males.
